newsitem.title: MEXICO: Pavarotti sings before 17,000 at Mayan ruins.
newsitem.headline: Pavarotti sings before 17,000 at Mayan ruins.

text.p: Italian tenor Luciano Pavarotti captivated about 17,000 people gathered over the weekend at one of Mexico's most famous Mayan ruins to hear the opera singer in a stunning setting.

Pavarotti's voice resonated between the pyramids and temples as he performed a dozen works, most of them pieces by Giacomo Puccini. The Saturday concert was televised to more than 120 countries, organisers said.
But Mexican newspapers on Sunday were not so enthusiastic, saying it lacked emotion. "A good concert, without being spectacular," the Reforma newspaper said.
The longest applause came after the finale duo of "La Boheme" with Italian soprano Carla Maria Izzo.
The music lovers in attendance, who paid between $50 and $1,500, were also treated to an interpretation by Pavarotti of "Granada," the song made famous by Mexican singer Agustin Lara.
Mexican President Ernesto Zedillo was among the high-profile guests at the concert.
